The effect of catalyst pellet size on nickel carbonyl-induced particle sintering under low temperature CO methanation J. Barrientos ⁎ N. González M. Lualdi M. Boutonnet S. Järås KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), Chemical Science and Engineering, Chemical Technology, Teknikringen 42, Plant 6, SE-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden KTH (Royal Institute of Technology) Chemical Science and Engineering Chemical Technology Teknikringen 42 Plant 6 Stockholm SE-100 44 Sweden ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The present work aims to evaluate the effect of catalyst pellet size on deactivation due to nickel carbonyl-induced particle sintering. For that purpose, a γ-Al2O3-supported nickel catalyst was prepared and tested under low temperature and high CO partial pressure. A total of four different pellet sizes were employed in the present study. It was found that the deactivation rate decreases with increasing pellet size. A very severe deactivation was observed when using small pellets. Large pellets exhibited instead a more stable performance. This difference in catalyst stability was explained by X-ray diffraction analyses which revealed that the growth of the nickel particles was very severe when using small pellets. An evaluation of heat and mass transfer phenomena in these four pellets was also conducted. It was found that, under the present low temperature reaction conditions, the temperature at the catalyst external surface can greatly differ from that in the bulk gas when using sufficiently large pellets. It was also shown that, for large pellets, the major part of the interior of the catalyst is exposed to negligible CO partial pressures and high temperatures, fact that can reduce the potential for nickel carbonyl formation. Nickel-based catalysts are widely used in this application due to their high activity and selectivity to methane [3]. Nevertheless, these are threatened to severe intrinsic deactivation phenomena. At high temperatures and high pressures of steam, there is a risk of thermal sintering of both the nickel particles and the support [4–6]. At low temperatures and high CO partial pressures, there is a potential for polymeric carbon formation [7–10] and carbonyl-induced nickel particle sintering [11–14]. Carbonyl-induced nickel particle sintering is a mechanism involving the formation of mobile Ni(CO)4 [11,15], and/or sub-carbonyl species (Ni(CO) x , x <4) [16,17], diffusion in the catalyst pores and subsequent decomposition over a nickel crystal. This type of mechanism leads to an excessive growth of the nickel crystals within days [13,18]. At very severe conditions Ni(CO)4 can diffuse through the catalyst bed and eventually, leave the catalytic reactor [11]. This phenomenon can be avoided by properly defining the inlet CO partial pressure and temperature in a methanation reactor [19,20]. Shen et al. [11] performed an excellent investigation on this type of deactivation using γ-Al2O3 supported nickel catalysts. In this study, they performed experiments at pressures up to 600kPa and temperatures between 400 and 740K. The spent samples were further analyzed in order to evaluate whether sintering or loss of nickel occurred. It was found that a criterion based on the equilibrium partial pressure of Ni(CO)4 could be established to identify safe and unsafe operating regimes. According to this work, safe operation can be achieved if the Ni(CO)4 partial pressure is kept below 10−6 Pa. This work is in well agreement with other literature studies in which nickel particle sintering at low temperatures has been observed [18,21,22]. Unfortunately, it seems that this criterion cannot be applied in large-scale fixed-bed methanation reactors. According to Rostrup-Nielsen [23]. in practice, carbonyl formation is not a problem at temperatures above 573K. For instance, in the ADAM I pilot plant [24], the inlet CO partial pressure and temperature in the first adiabatic reactor were 154kPa and 579K, respectively. According to the study of Shen et al. [11] these conditions were undoubtedly in the unsafe operating regime and therefore, carbonyl-induced Ni particle sintering should have occurred. Nevertheless, this phenomenon was not observed in approximately 1500h of operation [24]. More recently, Nguyen et al. [12] mentioned that methanation catalysts can function without significant carbonyl formation due to the presence of concentration and temperature gradients in the gas film surrounding the catalyst pellet. In this particular reaction, the CO concentration decreases through the gas film from the bulk gas to the catalyst. Since the methanation reaction is exothermic, the temperature also increases from the bulk gas to the pellet surface. In other words, the potential for Ni(CO)4 formation is lower at the catalyst surface than in the bulk gas and in consequence, the catalyst may function even though there is a risk for carbonyl formation in the bulk gas. This explanation can, from the author’s point of view, justify this inconsistency between the study of Shen et al. [11] and the catalyst performance observed in large-scale reactors [19,20,24]. The catalyst pellet size employed in the work of Shen et al. [11] was a fine powder (80/100mesh) whereas the catalyst used in the ADAM I pilot plant was the MCR-2X from Haldor Topsoe [20] which consists of 7-hole cylindrical pellets [12]. Therefore, it is possible that the influence of mass and heat transfer on catalyst performance is greater in the latter case, allowing for a successful operation in a regime in which, according to Shen et al. [11] carbonyl formation is problematic. Unfortunately, to the best of our knowledge, this pellet size effect has never been verified neither studied from a scientific perspective. There are very few studies working with large methanation catalyst pellets and none of these has addressed this issue [25,26]. Furthermore, it may be surprising that the methanation reaction over these catalysts can be externally mass transfer controlled at temperatures around 573K and so, lead to significant concentration gradients in the gas film surrounding the pellet. Therefore, a deeper insight into the effect of pellet size on this type of deactivation would be valuable. In the present work, a conventional catalyst consisting of nickel supported on γ-Al2O3 was prepared. A total of four different pellet sizes were prepared from the same catalyst batch. The catalyst pellets were tested at 583K, 2MPa and using an inlet H2/CO=3. These conditions are, according to Shen et al. [11], clearly favorable for carbonyl-induced particle sintering. The objective of the present work is to evaluate the effect of pellet size on this type of deactivation. For that purpose, the spent samples were analyzed in order to estimate the growth of the nickel particles. Finally, the temperature and concentration in the gas-solid interphase and in the interior of the catalyst pellets were estimated in order to offer a more comprehensive discussion of the results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A Ni-based catalyst containing 30wt% Ni was prepared by wetness impregnation of a γ-Al2O3 carrier. The γ-Al2O3 carrier was provided by Saint Gobain NorPro (product type: SA 6173) and consisted of cylindrical pellets with a diameter of 3.6mm and an average length of 5mm. Prior to impregnation, the support material was dried at 393K for 6h and then calcined in flowing air for 10h at 773K (heating rate: 1K/min). Then, the calcined pellets were impregnated with an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (puriss. p.a.; ≥98.5% (KT), Fluka). Approximately 5g of γ-Al2O3 pellets were immersed in a vessel containing 40mL of the precursor solution during 15h under stirring. Then, the solution was heated up at 393K until its evaporation. Finally the solid samples were dried at 393K for 3h and calcined in air at 723K for 3h (heating rate: 2.5K/min). This catalyst batch was used to prepare pellets of different sizes. For that purpose, some pellets were crushed into powder and sieved. Two powder fractions were employed in the present study. A fraction with pellet diameters in the range of 53–90μm and another in the range of 500–850μm. These two fractions were named “53–90μm” and “500–850μm”, respectively. Other cylindrical pellets were carefully cut in eight equal pieces. These pellets were named “1/8th pellet”. The approximate geometry of the “1/8th pellet” is illustrated later in this work for clarification. The original cylindrical pellet was also used in the present study and was named “Full-size pellet”. 2.2 Catalyst characterization techniques Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and porosity measurements were performed in a Micromeritics ASAP 2000/2010 unit. The sample was evacuated and dried overnight at 523K prior to analysis. The BET surface area was estimated by N2 adsorption at liquid nitrogen temperature at relative pressures between 0.06 and 0.2. The pore volume was estimated from a single adsorption point at a relative pressure of 0.998. The average pore diameter was estimated from the pore volume and the BET surface area assuming cylindrical pores. The pore size range was calculated with the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method using the adsorption isotherm. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on the unreduced and reduced catalyst as well as on the spent samples in a Siemens D5000 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (2θ =10−90°, step size=0.02°) equipped with a Ni filter. The average crystallite diameter of Ni (d(Ni0)XRD, nm) and NiO (d(NiO)XRD, nm) were estimated by using the Scherrer formula and assuming that the particles are spherical [27]. The NiO crystal size was estimated from the data in the 2θ range of 62–65°. The Ni crystal size was estimated from the data in the range of 50–54°. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was used to study the reducibility of the catalyst. TPR of the calcined sample was performed in a Micromeritics Autochem 2910 by flowing 5% H2 in Ar and increasing the temperature from ambient to 1200K (heating rate: 10K/min) while monitoring the H2 consumption by means of a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The degree of reduction (DOR,%) was estimated from TPR after in situ reduction of the catalyst at 773K for 4h (heating rate: 5K/min) in pure H2 flow. The DOR was calculated assuming that the unreduced nickel oxide was composed of Ni(II) as evidenced from XRD. Hydrogen-static chemisorption was performed on the fresh catalyst in order to estimate the nickel dispersion (DH,%) and the nickel crystallite size (d(Ni0)H, nm). The chemisorption measurements were conducted in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020C unit at 308K, after in situ reduction of the catalyst at 773K for 4h (heating rate=5K/min). The average particle size of Ni was calculated according to Ref. [28]: (1) d ( Ni 0 ) H = 0.97 D H × DOR The internal morphology of the “Full-size pellet” was observed with a Hitachi TM3000 scanning electron microscope (SEM) with an accelerating voltage of 15kV. For that purpose, the pellet was cut in half. An energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping was carried out by means of a Bruker Quantax 70 EDS detector in order to evaluate the homogeneity of nickel inside the pellet. The SEM-EDS analyses were performed at the Department of Inorganic and Structural Chemistry in Stockholm University. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic tests were performed in a down-flow stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (i.d. 9mm) with a catalyst loading of 50–100mg diluted with approximately 5g of SiC (average pellet size=75μm). The process conditions were: 583K, 2MPa and an inlet H2/CO=3. The same syngas flow (15NL/h) was used for the four experiments. The reactor tube was heated by means of an oven and the temperature inside the reactor was regulated by cascade control with one sliding thermocouple in the catalyst bed and another one placed in the oven. A detailed description of the equipment has been given elsewhere [29,30]. The dilution of the catalyst with a fine SiC powder was not only performed to improve the isothermal operation but also to minimize wall gas effects on pressure drop in the case of using large pellets. According to Eisfeld et al. [31] the selected SiC pellet size is adequate to suppress these effects in this reactor. The possibility of performing additional tests by diluting the samples with SiC pellets of similar size was also considered by the authors of the present work. However, this would significantly increase the volume of voids in the reactor when using large SiC pellets. In consequence, this would lead to considerably larger temperature differences in the reactor which would complicate the interpretation of the results. Prior to reaction, the catalysts were reduced in situ in pure H2 at atmospheric pressure and 773K for 4h (heating rate=5K/min). After reduction, the catalysts were cooled to reaction temperature (583K) and then flushed with He before increasing the pressure to the desired level. Afterwards, the methanation experiments started with a stepwise increase of the syngas flow, together with a stepwise decrease of the He flow, in order to avoid a large temperature rise in the catalyst bed due to the exothermic reaction. The syngas feed contained 2% N2 as an internal standard. The product gases were analyzed on-line by means of a GC Agilent 6890 equipped with a TCD and a flame ionization detector (FID). N2, CO, CH4 and CO2 were separated by a Carbosieve II packed column and analyzed on the TCD. The C1–C4 hydrocarbons were separated by an alumina-plot column and quantified on the FID. A detailed description of the product analysis and data treatment is given in [32]. The carbon-selectivity to long chain hydrocarbons (SC5+) was estimated according to: (2) SC 5 + = 100 − ( SC 1 − SC 2 − SC 3 − SC 4 − SCO 2 ) The H2/CO usage ratio (u.r.) was used as a measure of H2 consumption and is defined as [32]: (3) u . r . = 3 × SC 1 + 2.1 × ( SC 2 + SC 3 + SC 4 ) + 2 × SC 5 + − SCO 2 100 After 24h on stream, the syngas flow was replaced by helium flow and the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. Then, the helium flow was stopped and the spent samples were passivated by contact with air. The “53–90μm” spent sample was effectively separated from the SiC powder by means of a magnet. The other pellets were separated from the SiC powder by sieving. The spent samples were then crushed and analyzed by XRD in order to estimate the resulting Ni crystal size. 3 Mathematical modeling of the catalytic system 3.1 Estimation of concentration and temperature gradients in the gas film Prior to the estimation of the concentration and temperature at the gas-solid interphase it is necessary to define the reaction kinetics. The kinetics of CO methanation on Ni is usually described as a function of the partial pressure of H2 and CO. According to Sughrue and Bartholomew [33]. the reaction order for CO is negative but tends to zero with increasing temperature. The reaction order for H2 remains in the vicinity of 1. Indeed, at reaction temperatures similar to that of the present study, the kinetics of CO methanation have been successfully described with an irreversible first-order reaction in respect to H2 [33,34]. Therefore, this reaction kinetics was adopted in the present study. This kinetics allowed for the determination of the reactants concentration at the catalyst external surface by means of already developed mathematical expressions. Furthermore, numerical solutions of the effectiveness factor as a function of the Thiele modulus in non-isothermal systems have been already developed with this kinetics, fact that facilitates the comprehension of the results [35]. For an irreversible first-order reaction, the reaction rate in the pellet ( R H 2 ) considering both reaction and diffusional resistances is defined as [36]: (4) − R H 2 = a m × c H 2 , b 1 k c + 1 ( k'' ⋅ η ) = k observed × a m × c H 2 , b where “a m” is the specific external surface area of the catalyst pellet, “ c H 2 , b ” is the bulk concentration of H2. The term “k c” is the external mass transfer coefficient and “(k”·η) is a term considering both reaction and mass transfer inside the pellet. The term ‘k observed’ has been created for convenience and serves for the determination of (k′′·η). The term “k observed” was estimated for each experiment by assuming that the flow regime in the integral reactor is that of a plug-flow reactor. The concentration of H2 at the catalyst external surface ( c H 2 , s ) can be calculated as [37]: (5) c H 2 , s = c H 2 , b 1 + ( k ′ ⋅ η ) / k c The temperature at the gas–solid interphase (T s) can be calculated as follows [38]: (6) T s = T b + k c × ( − Δ H ˆ ) × c H 2 , b h × f where “T b“ is the temperature in the bulk gas, “ Δ H ˆ ” is the specific heat of reaction per mol of H 2, and “h” is the heat transfer coefficient in the gas film. The parameter “f” is the relative concentration difference in the gas film and represents the extent to which the reaction is externally mass transfer controlled. This parameter is defined as follows [38]: (7) f = ( c H 2 , b − c H 2 , s ) c H 2 , b The external mass transfer coefficient (k c) can be calculated by estimating the Sherwood number (Sh), the molecular diffusivity of H2 in the fluid ( D H 2 m ) and the mean spherical pellet diameter (d pellet) according to [38]: (8) k c = Sh × D H 2 m d pellet The Sherwood number was calculated by using the following equation, developed by Guedes de Carvalho and Alves [39], for particles immersed in packed beds consisting of smaller particles: (9) Sh ε bed = [ 4 + 4 5 × Pe 2 3 + 4 π × Pe ] 1 / 2 × [ 1 + 1 9 × Pe p ] 1 2 where “ε bed” is the bed voidage, “Pe” is the Peclet number based on the diameter of the catalyst particle and “Pe p” is the Peclet number based on the diameter of the inert particles (the SiC powder in the present study). The Pe and Pe p are defined as follows [39]: (10) P e = u 0 × d pellet × τ bed D H 2 , m (11) P e p = u 0 × d SiC × τ bed D H 2 , m where “u 0” is the uniform interstitial velocity, “d SiC” is the particle diameter of SiC and “τ bed” is the tortuosity of the bed. The latter can be estimated as follows [40]: (12) τ bed = 1 − ln ( ε bed 2 ) The molecular diffusivity of a single component in the fluid can be estimated according to Ref. [41]: (13) D i , m = ( 1 − y i ) ( Σ j = 2 n y i D i , j ) where “j” is a component in the system different than “i” and “y” is the molar fraction. The term “ D i , j ” is the binary diffusion coefficient of “i” in a component “j”. The binary diffusion coefficients were estimated by means of a method based on the Chapmann–Enskog kinetic theory reported in Ref. [41]. The heat transfer coefficient can be calculated according to Ref. [42]: (14) h = N u × λ fluid d pellet Here “λ fluid” is the thermal conductivity of the fluid and “Nu” is the Nusselt number. According to Pešić et al. [43] the following expression can be used to accurately estimate the Nu of particles immersed in a packed bed: (15) N u = 2 + 0.9 × R e 0.62 × ( d pellet d SiC ) 0.2 where “Re” is the Reynolds number and is defined as follows [43]: (16) R e = ρ × u 0 × d pellet μ where “ρ” and “μ” are the density and the viscosity of the fluid, respectively. These calculations were based on the composition and properties of the gas at the inlet of the reactor where there is the highest potential for Ni(CO)4 formation (583K, 2MPa and H2/CO=3). Finally, it must be mentioned that the influence of external heat and mass transfer limitations on the observed reaction rate was found to be negligible for the sample “53–90μm”. The following criterion, established by Mears [44], was used to determine whether heat transport in the gas film has a significant effect on the observed reaction rate: (17) | − Δ H ˆ × r observed × d pellet 2 × h × T b | < 0.15 × R × T b E a where “r observed” is the observed consumption rate of H2 per unit volume, “R” is the ideal gas constant and “E a” is the activation energy. 3.2 Estimations of temperature and concentration gradients inside the catalyst The temperature and concentration gradients inside the catalysts were estimated by solving simultaneous mass and heat balances in the different catalyst geometries. The commercial software COMSOL Multiphysics v5.0 was used to solve these equations for the different pellet models. A free triangular mesh was employed for the numerical computation. The boundary conditions (conditions at the gas-solid interphase) used in these calculations are those of the bulk gas (583K, 2MPa and H2/CO=3). At steady state, the reactants are transported inwards the catalyst by diffusion and are consumed within it by reaction. A single component mass balance in a volume element in the catalyst pellet becomes [42,45]: (18) D i , eff × ∇ 2 c i = ν i × r = ν i × A × exp ( − E a R × T ) × p H 2 where “D i,eff” is the effective diffusivity of a component “i” inside the catalyst pores, “ c i ” is the concentration of “i”, “ν i” is the stoichiometric coefficient, “r” is the reaction rate per unit catalyst volume, “A” is pre-exponential factor for a first-order reaction, “T” is the temperature and “ p H 2 ” is the partial pressure of H2. By analogy, at steady state, the heat produced by reaction is transported outwards the catalyst pellet by conduction. Expressing the specific reaction enthalpy per mol of H2, a heat balance in a volume element in the pellet becomes [42,46]: (19) ( D H 2 , eff × ∇ 2 c H 2 ) × Δ H ˆ = λ × ∇ 2 T where, “λ” is the effective thermal conductivity of the porous catalyst. Eq. (19) in integrated form becomes [46]: (20) Δ T = T − T s = − Δ H ˆ × D H 2 , eff λ × ( c H 2 , s − c H 2 ) Eq. (20) was shown by Prater [47] to be valid for all kinetics and to apply for any particle geometry. This relation was used by the COMSOL Multiphysics software instead of the differential heat balance since that simplifies the numerical computation. The effective diffusivity of H2 in the pores was calculated according to Ref. [41]: (21) 1 D i , eff = 1 D i , K , eff + 1 D i , m , eff where “D i,K,eff” is the effective Knudsen diffusivity and “D i,m,eff” is the effective molecular diffusivity in the fluid. The effective Knudsen diffusivity can be estimated according to Ref. [41]: (22) D i , K , eff = D i , K × θ τ = ( 2 3 × d pore 2 × R × T π × M i ) × θ τ where “D i,K” is the Knudsen diffusivity, “M i” is the molecular weight, “T” is the temperature in K, “θ” is the volume fraction of voids of the catalyst and “τ” is the tortuosity. The tortuosity value of γ-Al2O3 supports varies between 2.2 and 6.8 [41]. A value of 4 is usually found for these carriers [41] and therefore was used in the present study. The effective molecular diffusivity can be estimated according to Ref. [41]: (23) D i , eff = D i , m × θ τ The effective diffusivity was calculated for H2, CO, CH4 and H2O in order to compute their respective mass balances. The stoichiometry used was that corresponding to the CO methanation reaction. Finally, it may be noteworthy mentioning that in the present study the diffusion in the pores was controlled by the Knudsen diffusion for both reactants and products. To the best of our knowledge, very few information has been published on the thermal conductivity of porous catalysts. The major studies appear to report data obtained under vacuum or atmospheric conditions and at temperatures in the range of 298–453K [46]. The reported values of the thermal conductivity of alumina-based catalysts is in the range of 10−4 and 10−3 cal/(scmK) [48,49]. An estimation of the effective thermal conductivity was attempted by means of the method described by Butt [50]. By using this method, the estimated value of λ is approximately 2×10−4 cal/(scmK). It must be mentioned though that the methods established to estimate this parameter are based on several assumptions. Moreover, the value of the effective thermal conductivity has a critical impact on the temperature and concentration profiles inside the catalyst. Therefore, in the present study we offer an estimation of these profiles for different values of λ. The values used in the COMSOL computations are 2×10−4, 5×10−4 and 1×10−3 cal/(scmK). The pre-exponential factor was estimated from the observed initial activity of the sample “53–90μm”. The influence of internal heat and mass transfer limitations on the observed reaction rate was found to be negligible for this sample and therefore, the observed catalyst activity could be used to determine intrinsic kinetic parameters. The following criterion, developed by Weisz and Hicks for exothermic first-order reactions [35], was used to determine whether internal mass and heat transport limitations have a significant effect on the reaction rate: (24) r observed × d pellet 2 4 × c H 2 , s × D eff × exp ( γ × β 1 + β ) < 1 where “γ” expresses the sensitivity of the reaction rate to temperature and “β” represents the maximum temperature difference that can exist in the particle relative to the surface temperature. These two parameters are calculated as follows [35]: (25) γ = E a R × T s (26) β = ( − Δ H ˆ ) × D H 2 , eff × c H 2 , s λ × T s 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Catalyst characterization Table 1 shows the physical properties of the catalyst after calcination. The catalyst is characterized by a relatively high surface area and pore volume. The results from the BET N2 adsorption analysis indicate that the catalyst presents a monomodal pore distribution in the mesoporous range of 3–20nm. The values of the catalyst particle density and volume fraction of voids are also reported in Table 1 since these were employed for the estimation of the effective diffusivity. Table 2 shows the physicochemical properties of the catalyst. The DOR is 62% and therefore, the catalyst is not completely reduced after the activation procedure. This incomplete reduction of nickel oxide is most probably due to the presence of hardly-reducible nickel aluminates. This statement is supported by the H2-TPR profiles presented in Fig. 1 . As can be seen, the H2-TPR of the non-activated catalyst reveals the existence of nickel aluminates that are reduced around 1100K. The H2-TPR profile of the sample after activation at 773K, reveals that the reduction of these nickel aluminates does not occur, as expected. The estimated average nickel particle size obtained by H2 chemisorption and XRD analyses is approximately 10nm. The SEM-EDS images of the “Full-size pellet” are presented in Fig. 2 . The highlighted areas indicate the concentration of specific elements. The black areas correspond to plane defects or indicate the absence of the element evaluated. The Ni concentration profile along the pellet diameter is presented in Fig. 3 . As shown in these analyses, nickel is homogeneously distributed inside the catalyst pellet. 4.2 Catalytic testing The CO conversion during operation for the different samples is presented in Fig. 4 . As can be observed, the samples “53–90μm” and “500–850μm” presented a very fast decrease in CO conversion within the first hours on stream. In contrast, the samples “1/8th pellet” and “Full-size pellet” exhibited a more stable performance. The use of large pellets enhanced catalyst stability. This statement can be better observed by plotting the loss of relative activity against time on stream, which is presented in Fig. 5 . As can be seen, the deactivation rate appears to be faster the smaller the catalyst pellet size is. The samples 53–90μm” and “500–850μm” lost more than 95% of their activity in the first day on stream. The sample “1/8th pellet” lost approximately 13% of its activity. Finally the loss of activity for the largest sample, the “Full-size pellet”, was approximately 9%. Another interesting observation in this study is the difference in product selectivity between samples. This information is presented in Table 3 . According to Bartholomew et al. [51], the selectivity towards long chain hydrocarbons increases with metal dispersion for γ-Al2O3 supported nickel catalysts. Moreover, Hadjigeorghiou et al. [52] showed that the selectivity to methane also increases with increasing CO conversion. Therefore, the data presented in Table 3 corresponds to that of the first analysis, time at which the growth of the Ni particles has probably not occurred in a significant extent and the CO conversions are more similar between samples. As can be observed, the selectivity to methane is larger for larger pellet sizes. In general, there appears to be an increase in the selectivity to short-chain hydrocarbons with increasing pellet size. A possible explanation to this difference is that large catalyst pellets are exposed to higher temperatures due to the presence of significant temperature gradients in the gas film and/or inside the pellet. Another explanation can be that larger pellets are exposed to higher H2/CO ratios due to a faster diffusion of H2 compared to that of CO inside the pores. These differences in product selectivity support the fact that, under the conditions of the present study, the influence of mass and heat transfer is significant when using large pellets. It may also be important to comment that the activity of the “53–90μm” is apparently lower than other larger pellets as can be deduced by comparing the rates presented in Table 3. The activity of the “1/8th pellet” is, in this case, the highest. A possible explanation for this higher activity observed in larger pellets can be the presence of a large temperature gradient in the gas film and/or within the catalyst particle. As shown by Weisz and Hicks [35], the effectiveness factor can be higher that the unity in catalytic systems in which the sensitivity of the reaction rate to temperature is significant. In these cases, the functions relating the effectiveness factor and the Thiele modulus usually present a maximum. This fact could explain the lower activity observed for the “Full-size pellet” in comparison with that of the “1/8th pellet”. Nevertheless, it is also possible that the initial activity of the two smallest pellets is being underestimated since these presented faster deactivation rates. Unfortunately, it is not possible to accurately determine initial activities under these severe reaction conditions. It should be noted though that the difference in initial activity between the two smallest pellets, which deactivate at a similar rate, is already quite significant. Therefore, the former explanation should not be discarded. As explained in Section 2, the spent samples were analyzed by XRD in order to evaluate the growth of the Ni crystals. The diffractograms of the fresh catalyst and the four spent samples are presented in Fig. 6 . As can be observed in the figure, there is an evident growth of the Ni particles for the samples “53–90μm” and “500–850μm”. Sintering of the Ni particles is not apparent for the samples “1/8th pellet” and “Full-size pellet”. In Table 4 , the estimated Ni particle size of the spent samples is presented. The corresponding loss of Ni surface area, assuming that the particles are spherical, is also presented for its comparison with the loss of activity. The loss of Ni surface area is estimated in a 71% for both the samples “53–90μm” and “500–850μm”. It has been previously shown by Andersson et al. [53] that the methanation reaction on Ni is highly structure sensitive and that the reaction is fastest on step sites. Therefore, nickel particle sintering leads to not only to a decrease in nickel surface area but also to a decrease in the number of step sites. In turn, it is not surprising that these two samples lost more than a 95% of their initial activity. In conclusion, the observed deactivation of these two samples is probably caused, mainly, by carbonyl-induced particle sintering. Carbon deposition is probably significant at these conditions, however we believe that it played a less important role during these first 24h. The estimated Ni particle sizes of the spent “1/8th pellet” and “Full-size pellet” samples are slightly larger than the estimated initial nickel particle size (10nm). However, it must be noticed that the observed loss of activity for the “Full-size pellet” is lower than the estimated loss in Ni surface area. Therefore, it is not clear that sintering of the Ni particles occurred for these two samples. It is indeed possible that this slightly larger particle size is due to the precision of the XRD instrument as well as possible small differences in the initial average crystal size among the prepared pellets. Moreover, this difference in nickel particle size between these two spent samples does not explain the higher stability of the “Full-size pellet” in comparison to that of the “1/8th pellet”. We therefore speculate that carbonyl-induced particle sintering occurred in a lesser extent for the “Full-size pellet sample” or it simply did not occur for any of these two samples. Considering the latter case, we think that carbon formation would be mainly responsible for the observed loss of activity. In that case, it would not be very surprising to observe lower deactivation rates when using larger pellets. Larger pellets may be exposed to higher H2/CO ratios due to a faster diffusion of H2 in the catalyst pores, fact that enhances the hydrogenation of carbon [22]. It is noteworthy mentioning that the observed differences in Ni particle size cannot be justified by analyzing samples located in different reactor positions. The analyses correspond to a mixture of all the catalyst pellets in the reactor. Moreover, the entire catalyst bed was operating in an unsafe regime. In these experiments, the CO partial pressure along the reactor varied between 300 and 500kPa. According to the work of Shen et al. [11] safe operation is achieved at CO partial pressures below 25kPa at the reaction temperature of the present study (583K). In any case, an additional XRD analysis was performed for the sample “1/8th pellet”. However, this analysis was performed using only a catalyst pellet located at the inlet of the reactor, where there is the highest potential for carbonyl formation. The Ni particle size was estimated in 10nm, which is approximately the same value as that observed for the rest of the catalyst bed. Finally, it may be important to mention that this observed higher stability on larger pellets cannot be justified by differences between reactor temperature profiles. It is certain that the operation at isothermal conditions is more challenging when using larger pellets. Nevertheless, the highest temperatures observed in the axial temperature profiles are not significant enough to expose the catalyst to an operating regime in which, according to Shen et al. [11], carbonyl formation does not occur. The reactor axial temperature profiles obtained in these four experiments are presented in Fig. 7 . The two horizontal lines indicate the beginning and the end of the catalyst bed. As expected, the axial temperature differences are larger in the experiments using larger pellets. The maximum local temperature observed in these experiments is 590K. According to Shen et al. [11], these operating conditions are still clearly in the unsafe operating regime. As a result, it is possible to conclude that there is an effect of pellet size on catalyst stability at these conditions. The results show that the use of large pellets can reduce, or even suppress, deactivation due to nickel particle sintering. 4.3 Estimation of temperature and concentration gradients in the gas film The physical properties of the fluid and other parameters used for the estimation of the heat and mass transfer coefficients are shown in Table 5 . The estimated adimensional parameters as well as mass and heat transfer coefficients are presented in Table 6 . As can be observed, the use of larger pellets leads to smaller mass and heat transfer coefficients. In other words, the thickness of the gas film surrounding the catalyst increases with increasing pellet size. The estimated kinetic parameters as well as the H2 concentration and temperature at the catalyst external surface are presented in Table 7 . As can be observed, the concentration and temperature gradients are negligible for the sample “53–90μm”. The estimated concentration gradients in the gas film are insignificant for the four pellet sizes employed in this study. Nevertheless, the temperature at the catalyst external surface greatly exceeds that of the bulk gas for the samples “1/8th pellet” and “Full-size pellet”. According to Mears [44], this can occur in exothermic reactions due to a low thermal conductivity of the gas film and thus a great heat resistance. Nevertheless, the gas-solid interphase is still exposed to conditions at which carbonyl-induced sintering is still problematic (according to the criterion established by Shen et al. [11]). In conclusion, this higher stability observed for larger pellets cannot be justified by the presence of temperature and CO concentration gradients in the gas film. However, we do not discard that such a temperature difference allows for a successful operation if lower CO partial pressures are employed. Indeed, the employed inlet CO partial pressure in pilot reactors was considerably lower than the one employed in the present work [19,24]. Therefore, we hereby agree with the statements suggested by Nguyen et al. [12]. The conditions at the catalyst surface are probably safer than those in the bulk gas. We believe that this phenomenon was responsible for any possible inconsistency between the work of Shen et al. [11] and industrial experience. Furthermore, commercial methanation catalysts, may be more active and thus lead to larger concentration and temperature gradients. Moreover these catalyst pellets are probably larger than the ones used in the present study. Finally, it is possible that the external heat transfer coefficient in the present study is larger than that in commercial packed bed reactors. At these low gas velocities, the fluid flow around the catalyst is very different from that of an isolated object [39]. In other words, the boundary layer is large enough to comprise other solid objects around the catalyst. As a result, larger voids around the catalyst may lead to lower thermal conductivities and in turn, to lower heat transfer coefficients. Therefore, we think that the gas film temperature difference in a pilot reactors is larger than the one estimated in the present work. 4.4 Estimation of temperature and concentration gradients inside the catalyst pellets As explained previously, internal mass and heat balances were solved simultaneously by means of the software COMSOL Multiphysics in order to evaluate the temperature and CO partial pressure inside the different pellets. The kinetic parameters used to solve the mass balances are presented in Table 8 . The boundary conditions, conditions at the catalyst external surface, are those of the bulk gas (583K, 2MPa and H2/CO=3). It would probably be more realistic to use the values of concentration and temperature calculated in the previous section as boundary conditions. However, we preferred to use the same boundary conditions for all the pellets since that offers a clearer understanding of the influence of internal mass and heat mass transfer inside the different pellets. The three-dimensional slice temperature and CO partial pressure profiles of the four samples are presented in Figs. 8–10 for the models using effective thermal conductivities of 1×10−3, 5×10−4 and 2×10−4 cal/(scmK). As can be observed in all the figures, the larger it is the pellet size the lower it is the CO partial pressure in the catalyst center. Analogously, the larger the pellet the higher the temperature in the catalyst center. It is important to notice the crucial effect of the effective thermal conductivity of a catalyst on its resulting internal temperature and concentration profiles. As can be observed by comparing the color scales of these three figures, the lower the effective thermal conductivity the higher the temperature that can be reached in the catalyst center. Moreover, the lower it is the thermal conductivity the stiffer are the CO partial pressure gradients. This is due to the high sensitivity of the reaction rate to temperature. The reaction rate increases exponentially with temperature. Contrariwise, the Knudsen diffusion rate is proportional to T0.5. As a result, the CO concentration gradient becomes larger at higher temperatures. Therefore, small variations in the thermal conductivity can result in large differences in these profiles. This effect of the thermal conductivity can be easily seen by comparing the profiles obtained for the samples “1/8th pellet” and “Full-size pellet” in the different figures. It is noteworthy mentioning that the partial pressure of H2 is still significant where the CO partial pressure is negligible. As previously explained, the diffusion of H2 in the pores is considerably faster than that of CO. In turn, the H2/CO ratio increases significantly with the diffusion distance. This phenomenon, together with an increasing temperature, can explain the observed differences in product selectivity between samples. The most important information that should be deduced from these figures is that, for large catalyst pellets, it is possible that the catalyst center and the major part of the catalyst are exposed to negligible CO partial pressures. In other words, the major part of the catalyst is exposed to conditions at which carbonyl formation is not problematic. Nevertheless, the external surface of the pellet and part of its inner body is undoubtedly exposed to favorable carbonyl formation conditions. Therefore, we think that the presence of internal temperature and concentration gradients cannot suppress this deactivation mechanism but can reduce significantly the nickel particle sintering rate. In conclusion, it is probable that, in the present study, these phenomena explain the higher stability observed for larger pellets. It is believed by the authors that the temperature and CO partial pressure profiles in the different samples are similar to those presented in Fig. 10. In that case, it is reasonable that the samples “1/8th pellet” and “Full-size pellet” exhibited low deactivation rates compared to the other two samples. This, together with the fact that the temperature at the gas–solid interphase is slightly higher for these two larger pellets, are most probably the reason for these lower deactivation rates. Moreover, carbonyl species that can form close to the catalyst external surface, diffuse inwards the catalyst center where the concentration of these is lower. However, these species are less stable the closer these are to the catalyst center due to a decreasing CO concentration and in turn, these rapidly decompose. In other words, diffusion and decomposition of Ni(CO)4 over other crystals may not occur in this catalyst section exposed to high temperatures and low CO partial pressures. This deactivation mechanism may only occur close to the catalyst external surface. Unfortunately, diffusion of Ni(CO)4 outside the catalyst pellet and across the reactor cannot be discarded. It is therefore, that the presence of internal temperature and CO concentration gradients probably may not suppress this type of deactivation. Finally, we suggest that this type of deactivation can be suppressed not only by defining the reactor inlet conditions but also by properly defining the pellet geometry as well as the mass flux. Furthermore, the sintering rate may also be significantly reduced by selecting catalyst supports based on their thermal conductivity and pore structure. A proper understanding of mass and heat transfer phenomena may allow to operate at lower reactor inlet temperatures and ultimately, reduce recycling costs in adiabatic fixed-bed methanation reactors. 5 Conclusions In the present work, a conventional alumina-supported nickel catalyst was tested using four different pellet sizes in order to evaluate the effects of heat and mass transfer on catalyst performance and especially, on deactivation due to nickel carbonyl-induced particle sintering at low temperatures and high CO partial pressures. It was found, that the deactivation rate decreased with increasing catalyst pellet size. The two smallest pellets lost more than 95% of their activity in the first day on stream. The X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that a considerable growth of the nickel crystals occurred for these two samples. Contrariwise, the two largest pellets presented a considerably more stable performance and no significant growth of the nickel crystals was observed. In conclusion, the use of large pellets can reduce the risk for carbonyl formation. An evaluation of heat and mass transfer phenomena in these four catalytic systems was conducted. It was found that the use of large pellets in fixed bed reactors can lead to a significant temperature gradient in the gas film, even though the CO concentration gradient is relatively small. In consequence, the potential for carbonyl formation is lower at the catalyst surface than in the bulk gas. Therefore, safe operation can be achieved when using large pellets even though there is a high risk for carbonyl formation in the bulk gas. However, under the operating conditions of the present study, the temperature difference between the bulk gas and the interphase cannot clearly justify the observed enhanced stability when using large pellets. On the other hand, it was found that the CO partial pressure gradient inside the catalyst can be significant for the pellet sizes employed in this work. It was also shown that, for the two largest samples, most of the interior of the pellet is probably exposed to negligible partial pressures of CO. In consequence, most of the catalyst is not exposed to favorable carbonyl formation conditions. Therefore, we suggest that this phenomenon can also reduce considerably the deactivation rate due to this carbonyl-induced mechanism. coredata.dc:description: The present work aims to evaluate the effect of catalyst pellet size on deactivation due to nickel carbonyl-induced particle sintering. For that purpose, a γ-Al2O3-supported nickel catalyst was prepared and tested under low temperature and high CO partial pressure. A total of four different pellet sizes were employed in the present study. It was found that the deactivation rate decreases with increasing pellet size. A very severe deactivation was observed when using small pellets. Large pellets exhibited instead a more stable performance. This difference in catalyst stability was explained by X-ray diffraction analyses which revealed that the growth of the nickel particles was very severe when using small pellets. An evaluation of heat and mass transfer phenomena in these four pellets was also conducted. It was found that, under the present low temperature reaction conditions, the temperature at the catalyst external surface can greatly differ from that in the bulk gas when using sufficiently large pellets. It was also shown that, for large pellets, the major part of the interior of the catalyst is exposed to negligible CO partial pressures and high temperatures, fact that can reduce the potential for nickel carbonyl formation.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of catalyst pellet size on nickel carbonyl-induced particle sintering under low temperature CO methanation
